text: what happened in the past stays in the
past
right well not for our inner child as an
adult you may still struggle with the
pain of past traumatic experiences that
happened long ago they manifest as
wounds influencing your thoughts and
actions your inner child carries your
childhood experiences emotions and
beliefs when your inner child is
neglected you see Dr IC effects in your
adult life so are you carrying a wounded
inner child let's find
out number one distracted
Behavior distracted or avoidant behavior
can be common in individuals with
unresolved childhood trauma when you
experience trauma in your early years it
can affect your ability to focus
concentrate and stay present in the
moment engaging in activities like
substance abuse excessive shopping or
workaholism are risky and unhealthy ways
we escape and numb painful feelings
associated with childhood trauma they
distract us so we don't have to deal
with them by keeping busy you avoid
situations or thoughts that could
potentially trigger distressing memories
or emotions associated with your trauma
deep breathing exercises and focusing on
sensory experiences can help break these
Cycles number two lots of guilt I'm
wrong everything is my fault other
people are suffering because of me
childhood trauma goes hand inand with
guilt if you feel the need to constantly
apologize even when you haven't done
anything wrong that's a sign that your
inner child may be ridden with guilt if
your primary caregivers has made you
feel guilty about the cost or effort of
raising you it perhaps convinced you
that you were to blame in addition when
emotional or physical needs go unmet
during childhood you may blame yourself
for not deserving care and attention
experiences of bullying rejection or
social exclusion from your peers as a
kid may also lead to feelings of guilt
for not fitting in as a result you have
difficulty accepting yourself you
struggle with low self-esteem and
constantly seek validation from others
understanding that this guilt originated
from external influences can help you
separated it from your true self
number three eager to please do you feel
that your only worth lies in making
others happy if your sense of self-worth
is tied to the happiness of others it's
a sign that your inner child has been
possibly conditioned into being a people
pleaser you need to make others happy
trauma responses are commonly
categorized as fight flight or freeze a
fourth less disgusted response to early
trauma is called fawning or people
pleasing individuals who respond to
trauma with fawning or people pleasing
tend to seek safety by merging with the
best wishes needs and demands of others
Basher describes this as doing whatever
it takes to avoid conflict including
abandoning your own needs and going out
of your way to receive approval your
inner child may need reassurance and
unconditional love to break away from
this pattern sharing your thoughts and
feeling feelings can lead to deeper and
more authentic connections with those
around you number four the perfect
Pursuit perfectionism is linked to
Childhood drama childhood scars may
cause you to chase Perfection
relentlessly everything you do needs to
be perfect from dressing and cooking to
your work ethic you simply have to be
perfect and even when everything is
perfect something is always missing as a
child all you needed was love and
support growing up with highly critical
parents may have forced you to meet
their exceedingly high standards in
order for you to feel approved and so
you learn perfectionism as a coping
mechanism to help relieve the
defectiveness internalized during
childhood you are driven by an
underlying motivation to be better than
others to avoid rejection says
University of Rochester psychologist
Andrew Elliot overachieving becomes a
way for you to gain external validation
and prove your
worthiness number five speaking up for
yourself when you're small it's common
to feel your opinion does not matter or
is unnecessary when you were ridiculed
or yelled at for speaking up as a child
it can be challenging to advocate for
your needs as an adult Wellness expert
Dr Susan balias explains when you spend
a lot of your life around unsafe people
there are situations where staying
silent may be seen as adaptive
such as when ensuring personal safety or
avoiding conflict however it's essential
to find a balance between knowing when
to speak up and when to stay silent in
different
situations and number six
self-sabotage okay picture this you have
always dreamed of pursuing a career in
art but whenever you're on the verge of
submitting your artwork for an
exhibition you start doubting your
ability so you don't do it a child who
is violated particularly by a person of
trust may look at the world as unsafe
and view themselves as undeserving of
good things in life leading to
self-sabotage childhood trauma can
create a fear of success and the
associated responsibilities or
expectations that come with it so you
self-sabotage your own achievements to
avoid the potential pressure or judgment
that success may bring you actively seek
to fall back into the familiar Embrace
of failure this can manifest itself
self-sabotaging behaviors such as
procrastination perfectionism or
undermining one's own efforts
reparenting your inner child involves
giving yourself the unconditional love
and support you needed in your early
years by becoming the nurturing
protective parent your inner child needs
you can foster personal growth and
self-improvement addressing unresolved
emotional wounds from your past can help
create a more balanced and empowered
present working with a therapist is also
invaluable to help cope with your inner
child wounds can you relate to these
signs let us know below and if you found
this video helpful please give it a
thumbs up and subscribe for more for
more related content you can check out
our video on five things your wounded
inner child needs to hear right now
until next time thanks for being here
and thanks for not giving up on yourself
